25
UR:
https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2011-07983-006&site=ehost-live&scope=site
Persistent link to this record (Permalink):
https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2011-07983-006&site=ehost-live&scope=site
Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2011-07983-006&site=ehost-live&scope=site">The passing CCKs in Japan: Analysis on families of cross-border marriages between Japanese and Brazilian.</A>
Database:
PsycINFO

The Passing CCKs in Japan: Analysis on Families of CrossBorder Marriages between Japanese and Brazilian

Shuko Takeshita*

INTRODUCTION

In Japan, there were 44,701 cross-border marriages in 2006-the highest number ever on record. Currently, one out of every 16 marriages in Japan is a cross-border marriage. This increase in cross-border marriages has also led to an increase in the number of CCKs (Cross-Cultural Kids) of these marriages. The number of CCKs in Japan more than doubled over a period of 20 years, from 10,022 in 1987 to 23,463 in 2006. It is clear, then, that Japan is witnessing a growth in the number of cross-border marriages and CCKs, but is Japan truly making progress in terms of multiculturalism? In this paper, I will examine Japanese sociocultural systems in the context of CCKs with Japanese and Brazilian parents for the following two reasons.

First, from a historical perspective, the social acceptance of CCKs born from cross-border marriages can be seen as an index of the degree to which multiculturalism is progressing (Jansson, 1981). Therefore, this research will reveal whether the growing consensus that multiculturalism lags far behind despite the trend towards increased multiethnicity in Japan could be supported or otherwise.

Secondly, Brazilians are the biggest ethnic group among newcomers in Japan. The total number of Brazilians registered as residents in Japan in 2006 was 312,979, accounting for 15.0% of all registered foreign residents, and ranking third next to Koreans (28.7%) and Chinese (26.9%) (The Immigration Bureau, 2007). The increase in the number of Brazilian residents in Japan accompanies the increase in the number of the marriage between Japanese and Brazilian and CCKs of these marriages.

Most Brazilians living in Japan are of Japanese descent. As a result, there are a large number of couples comprising Japanese and Japanese-Brazilian among the cross-border marriages between Japanese and Brazilian. Cottrell (1990) stated that within the definition of crossborder or cross-national marriages, a cross-border marriage is not necessarily an interethnic marriage, but also includes marriages between two people of the same ethnic group but with different nationalities, and that a cross-border marriage is not necessarily an intercultural marriage. In the case of marriages between Japanese and Japanese-Brazilians, however, even if the marriage is within a single ethnic group, the social and cultural backgrounds of the

* Department of Asian Studies, Chukyo Women's University, 55 Nadakayama Yokone-cho, Obu Aichi, 474-8651, Japan.

parties socialized in each country differ, albeit to varying degrees. In this paper, I will look at marriages between Japanese and Japanese-Brazilians as cross-border marriages and marriages between two people with different nationalities and cultural backgrounds, and examine the conditions involving CCKs of these marriages. When considering CCKs with Japanese and Brazilian parents, rather than focusing on the contrasts between Brazilian and Japanese culture, I will investigate the path to multiculturalism. I hope that this research will contribute to the construction of a multicultural society.1

LITERATURE REVIEW

The concept of CCK first came about in the literature on TCK (Third Culture Kid) in the United States. R. H. Useem coined the term TCK after spending a year in India in the early 1950s. Initially they used the term "third culture" to refer to the process of learning how to relate to another culture (Useem et al., 1963); in time they started to refer to children who accompany their parents into a different culture as TCK (Pollok, 2008). Later, the term TCK came to have an even broader application, referring in general to the children growing up in an interstitial culture, or culture between cultures (Pollok and Van Reken, 2002).

Even among these children growing up in culture between cultures, however, there are many different circumstances in which these cultures intersect; for example, there are cases where children stay temporarily in the host society, with the understanding that they will return to their home country some day, in addition to children of cross-border marriages and children of immigrants (Cottrell, 2007). After considerable debate regarding who should be considered a TCK, Van Reken and Bethel defined CCK as "A person who has lived in—or meaningfully interacted with—two or more cultural environments for a significant period of time during developmental years," and positioned TCK as one of the CCKs. There are subcategories among the CCKs; i.e., Children of Bi/multicultural Parents, Traditional TCKs, Children of Immigrants, Educational CCKs, Children of Refugees, Children of Minorities, International Adoptees, Domestic TCKs, Children of Transmigrants (Van Reken and Bethel, 2005; Kamoto, 2007; Sekiguchi, 2008).

In the literatures, variations in CCKs' experiences are discussed along with overarching issues of social exclusion and stratification among CCKs. Most literatures on CCK focus on children of expatriates. Difficulties associated with reentry to the passport country are grief and loss, hidden immigrant, belonging and home. Despite the difficulties they face, most CCKs' experiences overseas can be beneficial by discovering a meaningful group identity in the sense of CCK (Pollok and Van Reken, 2002; Van Reken and Bethel, 2005; Cottrell, 2007). Sekiguchi (2003) was the first to use the concept of CCK in Japan, in her study of the identity formation among children of Japanese-Brazilians. Her research demonstrates that the perspective of CCK transcending existing categories connects children who are divided at a variety of boundaries or stratified, and has an empowering function. The analytical concept common to the literatures is coexistence in contrast to social exclusion and segregation.

Most literatures on CCK focus on children of expatriates or immigrants as I mentioned above. There have been a few literatures on CCKs born from cross-border marriages. Due to

1 I would like to clarify at the outset that in this paper, the term "Brazilian" includes Brazilians of Japanese descent, and "Brazilian culture" includes the culture unique to Brazilians of Japanese descent.

the steady increase in cross-border marriages in Japan, problems such as social exclusion of CCKs born from these marriages and stratification among them are issues requiring solutions. In this paper, I will use the term CCK to refer generally to children of cross-border marriages. This is because despite the fact that these children have diverse cultural backgrounds, the descriptive terms used in Japan tend to contain discriminatory nuances, and the positive aspects of these children as agents of multiculturalism are often overlooked.

The terms used in Japan to describe children with one Japanese and one non-Japanese parent have changed over the years: Half-breed child → Mixed-blood child → Half → International child → Double (Sekiguchi, 2003). Sekiguchi stated that the term "half-breed child" is a derogatory term used shortly after World War II to refer to a child born between a man in the American military and a Japanese woman. Kamoto (2008), on the other hand, points out that the terms "half-breed child" and "mixed-blood child" were used disdainfully before World War II, during the Japanese colonization of Taiwan, the Korean Peninsula and so forth, to refer to children born between Japanese and persons from the colonized regions. In either case, the terms "half-breed child" and "mixed-blood child" are similar in that they emphasize the nuances of differentiation between the controller and the controlled, or differentiation between a superior ethnic group and an inferior one.

The Japanese-English term "half" began to be used in the 1960s. "Cool-looking Halfs" appeared frequently on TV and in magazines in the 1970s, and the term was used with a positive nuance in general. Even today, the word can be found in Japanese dictionaries, "Half is a person of mixed blood," and is still used by many Japanese. It is important to keep in mind, however, that the English word "half also carries the negative nuance of something being "incomplete." The term "international child" appeared in 1979 and the term "double" in 1980, but neither of these have been generally recognized in Japanese society as yet (Sekiguchi, 2003; Kamoto, 2008).

Children of cross-border marriages have diverse cultural backgrounds. The term CCK has gained attention in recent years as a term that refers not only to children born of parents with different nationalities, but to children born of parents with different cultural backgrounds, even if both parents have the same nationality. CCKs of cross-border marriages between Japanese and Brazilian can have multiple identities-Japanese, Brazilian, "half (half Japanese), foreigner, or person of Japanese descent-but are these children with diverse cultural backgrounds accepted as agents of multiculturalism in Japan? And does Japan offer an environment that promotes such acceptance? I will examine these questions from the perspective of coexistence, as well as Japanese socio-cultural systems through CCKs.

CCKS FROM A STATISTICAL PERSPECTIVE

According to the research conducted by Ishikawa (2007) on the destinations selected by foreigners coming to Japan, one of the notable characteristics of persons coming to Japan from Brazil is that they tend to choose Aichi, Gifu, or Mie, the three prefectures that comprise the Nagoya metropolitan region, or else the central region of Shizuoka and Nagano, two prefectures with highly competitive manufacturing industries. Even during the recession that lasted from 1992 to 1996, there was a high growth rate in the Brazilian population in Nagano, Gifu, and Mie, three prefectures surrounding Aichi and Shizuoka prefectures. This increase resulted mainly from two factors: Due to the low Brazilian population in this region up to that time, it had the labor demand to absorb the increase even during a recession; and dispatch agencies in Aichi and Shizuoka Prefectures facing cancellation of work contracts and a dramatic reduction in the number of dispatched laborers were expanding into surrounding areas where Brazilians had not yet penetrated (Kajita et al., 2005).





Figure 2:Live Birth of CCKs in Japan: Japanese Father and Foreign Mother

As indicated in figure 1, "Live birth of CCKs in Japan: foreign father and Japanese mother," in 2006, fathers with Brazilian nationality ranked fifth after Korean, American, Chinese, and British, but there have been several past years in which Brazilian fathers surpassed British fathers to be ranked fourth. Looking at the nationality of foreign mothers, as shown in figure 2, "Live birth of CCKs in Japan: Japanese father and foreign mother," in 2006, mothers with Brazilian nationality ranked fifth after Philippine, Chinese, Korean, and Thai mothers. The number of CCKs born to a Japanese father and a Brazilian mother has remained unchanged at fifth since 1992, when Brazilian parents were added to the list of "Live birth by nationality of father and mother" published as part of "Vital Statistics of Japan."



Figure 4:Live birth of CCKs in Aichi, Gifu, Mie, Shizuoka, and Nagano Prefectures: Japanese father and foreign mother.



Looking at the number of CCKs born in Aichi, Gifu, Mie, Shizuoka, and Nagano Prefectures, however, as indicated in figure 3, the number of CCKs born to foreign fathers and Japanese mothers has regional characteristics that differ from nationwide trends. Since 1997, the number of CCKs born to Brazilian fathers and Japanese mothers has been second only to those born to Korean fathers and Japanese mothers. As shown in figure 4, the number of CCKs born to Japanese fathers and Brazilian mothers has hovered around fourth or fifth.

The ratio of CCKs born to Brazilian fathers and Japanese mothers in Aichi, Gifu, Mie, Shizuoka, and Nagano Prefectures among the total number of such children in all 47 prefectures of Japan has been over 40%. Meanwhile, the ratio of CCKs born to Japanese fathers and Brazilian mothers has remained at 30%-39%, and the number of such children in the five prefectures noted above accounts for roughly one third of the number in all of Japan. I therefore selected the five prefectures of Aichi, Gifu, Mie, Shizuoka, and Nagano as the focus of this study, and conducted a survey regarding issues related to language education and names among CCKs whose parents have Japanese and Brazilian nationality.

SURVEY OUTLINE

This research was conducted from October 2007 to March 2008 in Aichi, Gifu, Mie, Shizuoka, and Nagano Prefectures. It is based on interview surveys of 37 families of cross-border marriages between Japanese and Brazilian with children. The subjects were gathered through introductions from International Exchange Associations and city offices in the regions where many Brazilians live, as well as by assistants who used a mailing list for Japanese wives with Brazilian husbands. The snowball sampling method of word-of-mouth introductions was then utilized. Each family was interviewed one to three times, with each interview taking from one hour to as long as six hours. Most interviews were conducted in the subjects' homes, but some were held at coffee shops nearly located.

ATTRIBUTES OF SURVEY SUBJECTS

Of the 37 cases in this study, 13 were Japanese husbands and Brazilian wives, and 24 were Brazilian husbands and Japanese wives. The total number of the children was 59, with an average age of 7.0 years. Profiles of the survey subjects can be found in Appendix Tables 1 and 2. The duration of the marriage for Japanese husbands and Brazilian wives was 13.0 years, and the average ages were 43.1 years for husbands and 40.3 years for wives. With regard to the Japanese husbands' occupation, ten were company employees, and three were self-employed. While five of the Brazilian wives were interpreters or Portuguese teachers, four were housewives, two were part-timers, and two were self-employed. Regarding the educational history of the Japanese husbands, there were six high school graduates, five university graduates, and two vocational school graduates. While five of the Brazilian wives were junior high school graduates, four high school graduates, and four university graduates.

The duration of the marriage for Brazilian husbands and Japanese wives was 5.0 years, and the average ages were 32.2 years for husbands and 33.8 years for wives. The most common occupation for Brazilian husbands was workers in production processes (20 cases: 15 cases of indirect employment, three cases of direct employment, and two cases of part-timer), followed by office workers (two cases), carpentry (one case), and university graduate student (one case). For the Japanese wives' occupation, 14 were housewives, six were part-timers, and two were company employees, one was nurse, and one was massager. Regarding the educational history of Brazilian husbands, there were 11 high school graduates, 10 junior high school graduates, and three university graduates. While nine of the Japanese wives were high school graduates, six were junior college or vocational school graduates, six were university graduates, and three were junior high school graduates.

LANGUAGE EDUCATION

Of the 59 children in the subject families, 28 were aged six years or older; all were attending or had graduated from Japanese schools, and their Japanese friends functioned as the reference group. There was only one case in which the child was attending a public elementary school during the week and attending a Brazilian school on the weekends. The Brazilian spouses held Japanese schools in high regard because those schools offered artistic subjects (art, music, etc.) that are not offered at schools in Brazil, as well as education in all aspects of life, including ethics.

Regarding languages, most of the CCKs say, "As I am Japanese, I don't want to learn Portuguese." The opinions that "The child is living in Japan, so we want him or her to learn Japanese" and "If the child is going to study a foreign language, it should be English" were overwhelmingly more common among the subject parents than the opinion that "We want the child to learn Portuguese." It appears that childrearing practices in cross-border marriages between Japanese and Brazilian reflect a hierarchy of values inherent in the socio-cultural image of "advanced nations—developing nations," as well as the practicality and social evaluation of language and cultural capital in terms of "American culture vs. Brazilian culture" or "English vs. Portuguese" (Sekiguchi; 2003).

This approach is also manifested in Japanese in-laws who deter the parents from passing on Portuguese to the children. One Brazilian mother (Family AB) said: "When I spoke to my eldest son in Portuguese, I was cautioned by my mother-in-law, who said, 'Our heirs are Japanese, so speak to him in Japanese.' After that, I was unable to teach my son Portuguese." Another Brazilian mother (Family AJ) offered the following anecdote: "I started teaching Portuguese to my eldest child (7 years old), but if the child spoke to her grandmother or grandfather in Portuguese, for example saying maçñ (apple), they would correct her into Japanese, saying, 'No, that's ringo.' They tell me that if the child is going to learn a foreign language, English would be better." It is extremely difficult to teach the children Portuguese when the Japanese in-laws, and particularly the paternal in-laws, are living in the same home.

Many children tend to lose interest in Portuguese when they reach school age, saying "Because I am Japanese," and many parents lament this trend. One Brazilian mother (Family AD) with children aged 11 and 9 said, "Sometimes I rent a Brazilian video to watch, but nobody else (in the house) wants to watch it, so I watch it quietly at night, by myself. Those times, I feel like I am the only Brazilian in the house, and I feel lonely." This Brazilian wife come to want to be Japanese and then ended up regretting their own decisions earlier to sideline their Brazilianness. This is a common theme that arises in comments made by foreign spouses; namely, that when the children are raised as mono-cultural, the foreign spouse feels a sense of alienation, being the only foreigner in the family.2 The child's main language does not necessarily correspond to his or her identity, but there is a substantial overlap here.

2 In most of the families in this study, however, the children do not live completely separated from Brazilian culture; for example, the families eat Brazilian food occasionally.

It is difficult for children to form an identity as a Brazilian if they have been raised in an environment where they rarely hear Portuguese.

THE NAMES OF CCKS

When a birth is registered in Japan, the child is included in the Japanese parent's family register, and takes that parent's family name. In a marriage between two Japanese, because Japan does not recognize the use of separate surnames by husband and wife, either the husband's or the wife's name is used; as a rule, cases in which one of the parents has foreign nationality are treated as separate surnames. If a Japanese national married to a foreigner wishes to change his or her surname to the spouse's or combined surname of the two, the surname can be changed with a simple application to the municipal office, as long as the application is made within six months of the day of the marriage. If more than six months has passed since the day of the marriage, then an application for a change of surnames must be made to the municipal office after receiving authorization from a family court.

In Japan, where the use of separate surnames by husband and wife is not recognized in the case of marriages between two Japanese, it is difficult for a marriage to be recognized as a legal marriage in a social context if the husband and wife have different surnames. Furthermore, if the parent and child have different surnames, it is difficult for them to be recognized socially as parent and child. In Japanese society, where the same surname is used to designate a single nuclear family, the use of a different surname by only the mother or father will give rise to many day-to-day inconveniences.

Of the subjects in this study, in all 13 cases of Japanese husbands with Brazilian wives, the wife uses the husband's surname, as written in Japanese Kanji characters, as her regular name. As a rule, the Brazilian wife's passport shows her maiden name followed by her husband's Japanese family name written in Roman letters ("personal name" + "Brazilian family name" + "husband's Japanese family name"),3 but in their daily lives in Japan, these women regularly use their husbands' Japanese family names, and do not use their Brazilian family names. Of the 24 cases of Brazilian husband and Japanese wife, seven couples used separate surnames, while one couple used a combination of the two, 15 changed to the Japanese family name of the Japanese-Brazilian husband, and one changed to the husband's Brazilian family name.

In Japan, with the exception of foreigners whose names can be written in Kanji characters (e.g., Chinese or Korean), foreigners generally write their names using the Katakana Writing system. Katakana is generally used for writing foreign words, so a name written in Katakana instead of Kanji indicates that the name is a foreign one. The Japanese names of JapaneseBrazilian are written in Katakana, but among the subjects in this study, 12 of the 15 Japanese couples whose wives changed their names to that of the Japanese-Brazilian husband began using the Kanji form of the name as the common name before the time when a child entered kindergarten. In all three cases where the Kanji form is not used as the common name, the children had not yet reached school age.

3 Some of the Brazilian wives in this study had changed the names in their passports from their maiden name to their husband's Japanese surname in Roman letters.

Regarding personal names, of the 59 children in the study, 32 have only Japanese names, and 27 have both Japanese and Brazilian names, but only three actually used their Brazilian names in everyday life. All three of these children are of pre-school age; one is going to the kindergarten of an American school and using his Brazilian name. An overwhelmingly large number of these children were using only Japanese names, at 56 out of 59.

There is a strong tendency for the parents to use Japanese names because they believe that if the child uses only a Japanese name, he or she will be more readily accepted by classmates. As a result, many of the children in the study are not even aware that they have Brazilian names. As one Japanese father (Family AG) said, "Sometimes I tell my children, 'You have two nationalities, Brazilian and Japanese, and you have two names, too,' but they don't seem to understand." A daughter (Family A A; 21 years old) said, "I have both the Japanese name and the Brazilian name. Even though I'm called by my Brazilian name, I'm afraid I won't recognize it. I'll have to choose either Japanese or Brazilian nationality soon.4 Of course, I'll choose Japanese nationality. I don't have an awareness of myself as a Brazilian." A son (Family AK; 11 years old) showed a strong resistance to be being called by his Brazilian name. "When I was called by my Brazilian name, I was teased about it in school." In this case, because the child felt awkward in the midst of a "Japanese school culture where it is better to be like everyone else," his parents stopped calling him by his Brazilian name.

A few parents have tried to use both the Brazilian name and the Japanese name in kindergarten or school, but have received directions from the teacher that it might be better to use only a Japanese name. One Japanese mother (Family BP), when entering her son named Gabriel-Akira in a nursery school, was told by the nursery school teacher, "It's better to be like everyone else, so your son should just use Akira." The mother replied, "I want you to call him Gab-chan (the Japanese diminutive) without hiding his Brazilian name or background." She explained, "Even if he is teased, I want him to become strong enough that he can shake it off easily. I want him to grow up being proud that he is half Brazilian." Names function as one means of defining the self, and as an index of social and cultural identity (Hatano, 2001). Most of the children in this study had very little awareness that their Brazilian names, which had never been used, were in fact their own. Although they have dual nationality, they only form an identity as a Japanese.

THE PASSING CCKS

In Japanese society, which emphases uniformity and homogeneity, using a Japanese name is one method of resolving the issue of being different from others. Conversely, some Brazilians of Japanese descent take advantage of the dual identity placed upon them by Japanese society-that of Japanese and Brazilian-and refer to themselves as Brazilian or Japanese depending on the situation (Yamanouchi, 1998). In cases where one cannot tell at first glance that a child is a CCK, or when the child lives in a metropolitan area with high anonymity, there

4 Article 14, Paragraph 1, of the Nationality Law stipulates that "A Japanese national having a foreign nationality shall choose either of the nationalities before he or she reaches twenty two years of age if he or she has acquired both nationalities on or before the day when he or she reaches twenty years of age or, within two years after the day when he or she acquired the second nationality if he or she acquired such nationality after the day when he or she reached twenty years of age."

Therefore, if the person does not choose Japanese nationality within the designated time period, Japanese nationality will be lost, but Brazilian nationality is not necessarily lost as a result of declaring the choice.

is a tendency for the child to hide the fact that one parent is Brazilian. One daughter (Family AH; 25 years old) living in X City, which has a large Brazilian population, made the following comments: "I wasn't educated as Brazilian by my parents. In fact, I am Japanese. If you say your parent is Brazilian, you will become the target of prejudice. So, you'd better pass." To become a passing CCK is one strategy for avoiding discrimination and prejudice, but it cannot be called true coexistence.

Komai (2006) describes two predominant situations in present-day Japan: "Passing," in which foreigners conceal their presence in Japanese society, and "Segregation," in which Japanese and foreigners avoid contact and remain alone from one another. The former is seen among Koreans in Japan, and the latter is seen between Japanese and Brazilians. However, it seems that even if one form is more characteristic for one group than another, in fact both forms work in conjunction with each other for any given group. It is precisely because of the fear of segregation or stigma that Koreans in Japan try to pass as Japanese. It is also because of such fear that Japanese-Brazilians are starting to pass.

The situation differs, however, in the case of children who are easily recognizable as being of "mixed blood," as they continue to be visible CCKs. The three component elements of ethnicity-lineage, culture, and nationality-are not given meaning with equal weighting; rather, "lineage" takes superiority (Fukuoka, 1998). Lineage includes the characteristics of outward appearance. One girl in the study (Family BM; 11 years old) was bullied on several occasions since the time she was eight years old, and sometimes refused to go to school. The BM family, which lives in a prefecture-run housing complex where 60% of the residents are Brazilians or Peruvians, go about their lives within, a network of Brazilians. The main language spoken in the home is Portuguese, and the child goes to a public elementary school, but goes to a Brazilian school only on weekends.

The mother says, "The fact that many Brazilians live in this region is the very reason that bullying occurs. Many crimes are committed by Brazilians, so Japanese parents tell their children not to play with Brazilian children. That affects the children, and it leads to bullying." The child, however, has a strong awareness of herself as a Japanese. She says, "I am Japanese. I've only been to Brazil twice; I was born in Japan and I go to a Japanese school." She then asked the author, "I'm Japanese, am not I?" as though seeking confirmation. During the interview, she frequently emphasized that she was Japanese, perhaps due to her concerns about becoming the target of bullying if she was not Japanese. It appears that this girl feels a gap between the awareness of those around her resulting from the characteristics of her outward appearance and her own identity as a Japanese, which was forming gradually. It gave her a feeling of some instability in that identity despite her young age.

The child described above was the only one among the subjects to have experienced bullying, but many parents are concerned that their own children will be bullied in the future. These concerns are particularly strong when one parent is not of Japanese descent. One Japanese mother (Family BG) often takes her 8-month-old son to a nearby children's play center. "When I tell people we live in Z residential block," she says, "they say with a distasteful tone, 'That's where many foreigners live, isn't it?' The atmosphere makes it difficult to say that my son's father is Brazilian. Fortunately, he looks a lot like me, so it's OK, but if it became known that his father is Brazilian, we couldn't go to the children's play center anymore. The fact that there are many Brazilians in this region makes the prejudice worse."

Though CCKs should be a bridge between Japan and Brazil, there are conditions that make it difficult for them to be proud that they are Brazilian. Following are three possible reasons that a negative image of Brazilians has been cultivated leading to the existence of discrimination. The first reason has arisen frequently from the informants during the interview, that as more news stories cover crimes committed by Brazilians, the image which Japanese residents have of Brazilians has deteriorated in regions where many Brazilians live. The negative opinions of regional residents regarding the increase in the foreign population in Japan tend to be affected by media reports of crimes committed by foreigners (Shishido and Iwai, 2009).

The second reason can be derived from the relationship between the stratification of the global labor market and the socio-economic status of Japanese-Brazilians. There are two types of demands for foreign workers in Japan: as a strategy for growth and as a solution for the shortage of labor force (Kajita, 1994). The strategy for growth mentioned here is implemented by large corporations, which employ foreign specialists to promote globalization, and to prepare Japanese companies for entry into overseas markets. Measures aimed at solution for the shortage of labor force, on the other hand, are being implemented mainly by small and medium-sized companies, and by subcontractors. Amid the shortage and the aging of the Japanese labor force, these companies are employing non-Japanese workers for unskilled labor as a means of securing cheaper, younger manpower.

Government measures related to the immigration of Japanese-Brazilians are tied into the latter mentioned above. As a result of an amendment to the Immigration Control Act (The Immigration Control and Refugee Recognition Act) in 1990, the Japanese government granted 2nd and 3rd generation Japanese unrestricted visa status to work in Japan. The entry of foreigners with the purpose of unskilled labor is prohibited in Japan. Even so, there was a great demand for unskilled foreign laborers. This 1990 amendment to the Immigration Control Act is generally assumed that Japanese descent was expected to make up a part of this group.5 The employment of Japanese-Brazilians is mainly indirect through dispatched agencies. They work as dispatched laborers who could be employed and fired depending on the state of the economy at any particular time. They take up unstable positions, and remain at the bottom of the labor market (Enari, 2002; Iguchi, 2008).

The third reason is that in Japanese society, there is a tendency to view the emigration from Japan to Brazil as something dishonorable (Kajita, 1994). Japanese-Brazilians are not foreigners who suddenly appeared in Japan in the latter half of the 1980s. They represent an extension of a trajectory that combines the history of Japanese emigration that began 100 years ago and the nature of Brazil, a multiethnic nation that welcomed those Japanese immigrants (Fukazawa, 2003). When Japan was still very poor, many Japanese emigrated to Brazil and other countries looking for a way to make a living. During the period of the bubble economy

5 According to Kajita et al. (2005), the change in the legal status of ethnic Japanese was made in relation to other policy issues; namely, resolving the issue of third-generation Koreans in Japan. Like first-generation and second-generation Koreans in Japan, third-generation Koreans are granted visa status as "special permanent residents," and there are no restrictions on working in Japan. There was a need to grant legal status to ethnic Japanese that would not place these individuals at a relative disadvantage in comparison to these "special permanent residents." When the Immigration Control Act was amended, the legal status of ethnic Japanese living outside of Japan was clarified.

in Japan, from the latter half of the 1980s, a reversal of this phenomenon began, as Japanese-Brazilians came to Japan looking for work as a result of inflation and stagnation in the Brazilian economy. This phenomenon was further accelerated by the 1990 amendment to the Immigration Control Act mentioned above.

CONCLUSION

With regard to language education, very few of the families in this study were providing their children with education in the Portuguese language. The children's first language is Japanese, and an overwhelming number of parents want their children to learn English as a second language rather than Portuguese. A hierarchy of language esteem exists in Japanese society. Among the families with parents of different native language, non-Japanese parent's native language is less used by children as well as Japanese parents in the Japanese-non-English families than in Japanese-English families (Yamamoto, 2002). This tendency became clear in the current research as well.

Regarding the children's surnames, in the case of families with a Japanese husband and a Brazilian wife, there is a strong tendency for the wife to take the husband's surname, and in the family register, the children use the Japanese father's surname. Also, in the case of families with a Brazilian husband and a Japanese wife, there is a tendency for the children to use the Japanese mother's surname in the family register, but if the father is a Japanese-Brazilian and has a Japanese surname in Katakana form, then there is a tendency for the wife to change her surname to the husband's, and to use the Kanji form of the Japanese surname as the common family name. Regarding personal names, there were extremely few cases in which the child used a Brazilian name. Notably, parents with children who are not immediately recognizable as CCKs based on characteristics of outward appearance have developed strategies for avoiding discrimination and prejudice through passing.

The perception of the parents is the main reason for the strong tendency toward passing among CCKs of cross-border marriages between Japanese and Japanese-Brazilians. JapaneseBrazilians have experienced an identity crisis: When they were in Brazil, they were called "diligent Japanese," and when they came to Japan, they were called "foreigner" or "Brazilian." Those Japanese-Brazilians who marry Japanese were to some extent already moving towards putting their Brazilianness behind them, and they raise their children as Japanese. They seek higher social status by living as Japanese. As a result, Brazilian parents feel a sense of alienation, and sometimes ended up regretting their own decisions to sideline their Brazilianness.

The other reason is the problems of Japanese schools. There are many Korean students attending Japanese schools, but they often use Japanese names, so only the teachers and school administrators know their background. Government policy in Japan with regard to Koreans in Japan for many years has always been a strong policy of assimilation,6 as indicated by the old expression "Assimilation or exclusion" (Fukuoka and Tsujiyama, 1991). As a

6 Government policy in Japan with regard to Koreans during Japan's colonial period (1910-1945) was a policy of assimilation, characterized by the enforced use of the Japanese language and the enforced changing of names (from Korean to Japanese names; 1939). Government policy after WWII with regard to Koreans in Japan was also a strong policy of assimilation (Fukuoka and Tsujiyama, 1991).

result, traditional Japanese school culture has exerted a strong oppressive force on these Korean students. Today's policy is not explicitly mono-cultural in the way that earlier policy was. However, despite those superficial differences, there are still substantial informal barriers to multiculturalism, stemming from the negative image of many foreigners in Japan, and the ongoing assumption that Japan has a unified cultural practice that foreigners must assimilate.

CCKs with two nationalities and cultural backgrounds should be guaranteed the right to enjoy the benefits of maintaining and developing an identity as a Japanese, in addition to one more identity.7 To achieve this, we need to encourage a new awareness of CCKs as agents for a transition from a monocultural system to a multicultural system, not only in Japanese schools, but in Japanese society as a whole.8

7 The average age of the 59 children covered in this study was a fairy young 7.0. I intend to conduct a follow-up study to examine CCKs as agents of multiculturalism.

8 This paper is part of the results of research conducted as Platform Research (B), recipient of a Grant-inAid for Scientific Research, Japan Society of the Promotion of Science: "Geographical research on the causes and impact of the increase in cross-border marriages in modern Japan" (representative researcher: Yoshitaka Ishikawa).

Title:
The past, present, and future of cross-cultural management education: The educators' perspective.
Authors:
Szkudlarek, Betina, Department of International Business, University of Sydney Business School, NSW, Australia
McNett, Jeanne, D'Amore-McKim School of Business, Northeastern University, Boston, MA, US
Romani, Laurence, Centre for Advanced Studies in Leadership, Stockholm School of Economics, Stockholm, Sweden
Lane, Henry, D'Amore-McKim School of Business, Northeastern University, Boston, MA, US
Source:
Academy of Management Learning & Education, Vol 12(3), Sep, 2013. pp. 477-493.
Page Count:
17
Publisher:
US : Academy of Management
ISSN:
1537-260X (Print)
1944-9585 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
management education, cross-cultural management, educators, teacher perspective, business curricula, learning environment
Abstract:
In a series of interviews with leading cross-cultural management (CCM) educators, we examine the state of the CCM field within business education. We invited eight prominent scholars and executive educators to consider the following main questions: What is the role of cross-cultural management in business curricula? What challenges do we face teaching this material? How can we create an engaged learning environment with the diverse audiences we encounter in our classrooms, and what theoretical frameworks best support these efforts? Last what is the future of cross-cultural management education? What changes and challenges can we expect? The learnings that emerged from our interviews are grouped around three main themes: the content of what we teach, our understanding of audiences with whom we work and their evolving expectations of cross-cultural management education, and the role, preparation, background and assumptions of the educators. This series of interviews contributes to highlight current trends in cross-cultural management education: a shift in content from knowledge to conditions of knowledge creation, a transition from monocultural audiences toward biculturals and global cosmopolitans, and finally, educators' changing responsibility from providing knowledge to developing and honing responsible, tolerant, and resilient global citizens. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Business Education; *Curriculum; *Management Training; *Teacher Attitudes; *Teaching; Cross Cultural Communication; Cultural Sensitivity; Professional Competence

Record: 154
Title:
The presence of absence: Mapping postcolonial spaces.
Authors:
Lorenz, Helene Shulman, Pacifica Graduate Inst, CA, US
Source:
Depth psychology: Meditations in the field. Slattery, Dennis Patrick (Ed); Corbett, Lionel (Ed); pp. 225-243; Einsiedeln, Switzerland: Daimon Verlag; 2000. 273 pp.
Page Count:
19
ISBN:
3-85630-597-1 (Paperback)
Language:
English
Keywords:
depth psychology, multiculturalism, sociocultural factors, social change
Abstract:
Conquest, land-theft, slavery, and genocide do not fit easily into heroic narratives of national destiny. When these brutalities are not publicly named and mourned, a habit of dissociative thinking is hardened into a cultural complex. The instinct of depth psychology is to approach these matters by climbing up to the peaks of a universalist discourse. This instinct is as much a social as a personal therapy. A public restoration process will require much more mature, self-conscious, and sophisticated individuals for the dialogue of the future among communities. Those who are inexperienced in negotiating multiple cultural codes because they live in monocultural environments will need to learn the arts of mestizaje and conversation in uncomfortable borderlands. Many people will be needed to create together the new decentered environments where all can reclaim desire, meaning, magic, and possibility. If it enters the vale, depth psychology has an important contribution to make in remapping of discontinuous and multiple notions of self and other, consciousness and unconscious, that must be the basis of restorative encounters and acts of love. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)
Subjects:
*Depth Psychology; *Sociocultural Factors; *Multiculturalism; Theoretical Interpretation
PsycINFO Classification:
Culture & Ethnology (2930)
Population:
Human
Intended Audience:
Psychology: Professional & Research (PS)
Format Covered:
Print
Publication Type:
Book; Edited Book
Document Type:
Chapter
Release Date:
20011003
Accession Number:
2001-18602-014

12

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 155
Title:
The reaffirmation of cultural identity in cross-cultural encounters.
Authors:
Kosmitzki, Corinne, U California, Berkeley, CA, US
Source:
Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin, Vol 22(3), Mar, 1996. pp. 238-248.
Page Count:
11
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
0146-1672 (Print)
1552-7433 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
intercultural contact, facilitation of cultural identification with native or nonnative cultural group, bicultural vs monocultural 16–70 yr olds, US & Germany
Abstract:
Examined the relation between cultural contact and psychological aspects associated with cultural identity, as conceptualized in 2 research approaches: social identity theory and acculturation research. The groups studied were German and US American Ss (aged 16–70 yrs) who either lived in the respective nonnative culture (biculturals) or had no direct contact (monoculturals). A total of 291 Ss provided information about their sociocultural backgrounds and their cultural experiences, and they rated how characteristic each of 120 trait-attributes was of themselves, their native cultural group, and their nonnative cultural group. Comparisons between monocultural and bicultural groups revealed a reaffirmation effect. Compared with monoculturals, biculturals saw themselves as more similar to their native cultural group, they evaluated that particular group's attributes more positively, and they saw the 2 cultural groups as less similar to each other. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Acculturation; *Culture (Anthropological); *Ethnic Identity
PsycINFO Classification:
Culture & Ethnology (2930)
Population:
Human
Age Group:
Adolescence (13-17 yrs)
Adulthood (18 yrs & older)
Aged (65 yrs & older)
Methodology:

Record: 156
Title:
The relevance of race for the study of sexuality.
Parent Book Series:
Blackwell companions in cultural studies
Authors:
Ferguson, Roderick A., Department of American Studies, University of Minnesota, Twin Cities Campus, Twin Cities, MN, US
Source:
A companion to lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and queer studies. Haggerty, George E. (Ed); McGarry, Molly (Ed); pp. 109-123; Malden: Blackwell Publishing; 2007. xviii, 478 pp.
Page Count:
15
ISBN:
1-4051-1329-4 (Hardcover)
978-1-4051-1329-8 (Hardcover)
Language:
English
Keywords:
race, sexuality, epistemology, intersectionality, queer studies, racialized sexualities, Foucault
Abstract:
The author examines the modes by which a generation of scholars has established race and sexuality as mutually constitutive. Interrogating the work of the axiomatic in confining such epistemological interventions in queer studies to the dead category of "self-evident truths," the author insists that "intersections" be rigorously historicized rather than merely asserted as structural. This process involves fracturing dominant narratives of both sexual and racial formation, as well as their imbrications, to expose forgotten or incomplete sites of mutual construction. The author's project is to reanimate intersectionality, both refusing it as an already constituted category and refusing to abandon it. The study of racialized sexualities, in this framing, revises Foucauldian histories of sexuality and reworks the relationships between sexuality and epistemology and between sexuality and power. In entwined genealogies of the intersectional analyses that have historicized racial formations and monocultural Foucauldian histories of sexuality, the author forcefully elaborates the ways in which race rewrites the history (and present future) of sexuality studies. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (introduction)
Subjects:
*Homosexuality; *Race (Anthropological); *Sexuality; Epistemology; Psychological Theories
PsycINFO Classification:

Record: 157
Title:
The roads less traveled: Mapping some pathways on the global mental health research roadmap.
Authors:
Fernando, Gaithri A., Department of Psychology, California State University, Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA, US, gfernan2@calstatela.edu
Address:
Fernando, Gaithri A., Department of Psychology, CSU Los Angeles, 5151 State University Drive, Los Angeles, CA, US, 90032, gfernan2@calstatela.edu
Source:
Transcultural Psychiatry, Vol 49(3-4), Jul, 2012. pp. 396-417.
Page Count:
22
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
Other Journal Titles:
Transcultural Psychiatric Research Review
ISSN:
1363-4615 (Print)
1461-7471 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
global mental health research, mental health services
Abstract:
The global mental health (GMH) research agenda should include both culture-general and culture-specific perspectives to ensure ecological validity of findings. Despite its title, the current GMH research agenda appears to be using a monocultural model that is individualistic, illness-oriented, and focused on intrapsychic processes. Ironically, issues of culture are prominently absent in many discussions of global mental health. This paper highlights some issues and concerns considered key to conducting ecologically valid and socially responsible GMH research. The concerns are particularly directed at researchers from dominant cultures who are working in low-income countries. Central to these issues is the balance between etic and emic perspectives in assessment, diagnosis, and intervention, as well as language, engagement of stakeholders and their agendas, and evaluation of the benefit of interventions to the community. New terminology is proposed that identifies broad cultural groups, and recommendations provided for a research agenda to encourage both basic and applied research that mutually benefits all stakeholders in the GMH research endeavor. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Mental Health; *Mental Health Services; *Global Health
PsycINFO Classification:
Health & Mental Health Services (3370)
Population:
Human
Tests & Measures:
Global Assessment of Functioning Scale
Format Covered:
Electronic
Publication Type:
Journal; Peer Reviewed Journal
Document Type:
Journal Article
Release Date:
20121105
Correction Date:
20130909

Record: 158
Title:
The subtlety of sound: Accent as a marker for culture.
Authors:
Dehghani, Morteza, Brain and Creativity Institute (BCI), University of Southern California, Los Angeles, CA, US, mdehghan@usc.edu
Khooshabeh, Peter, University of Southern California, Los Angeles, CA, US
Nazarian, Angela, University of Southern California, Institute for Creative Technologies, Los Angeles, CA, US
Gratch, Jonathan, University of Southern California’s (USC), Institute for Creative Technologies, Los Angeles, CA, US
Address:
Dehghani, Morteza, Department of Psychology, University of Southern California, Los Angeles, CA, US, 90089, mdehghan@usc.edu
Source:
Journal of Language and Social Psychology, Vol 34(3), Jun, 2015. pp. 231-250.
Page Count:
20
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
0261-927X (Print)
1552-6526 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
accent, culture, frame-switching, biculturalism
Abstract:
Aspects of language, such as accent, play a crucial role in the formation and categorization of one’s cultural identity. Recent work on accent emphasizes the role of accent in person perception and social categorization, demonstrating that accent also serves as a meaningful indicator of an ethnic category. In this article, we investigate whether the accent of an interaction partner, as a marker for culture, can induce cultural frame-shifts in biculturals. We report the results of three experiments, performed among bicultural and monocultural individuals, in which we test the above hypothesis. Our results demonstrate that accent alone can affect people’s cognition. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Group Dynamics; *Ingroup Outgroup; *Social Identity; *Sociocultural Factors; Cognition; Language
PsycINFO Classification:
Social Psychology (3000)
Population:
Human
Male
Female
Location:
US
Age Group:
Adulthood (18 yrs & older)

Individualism and Collectivism Scale

Record: 159
Title:
The within-person dynamics of intrinsic and extrinsic motivation, affective states, and cultural identification: A diary study of bicultural individuals.
Authors:
Perunovic, Wei Qi Elaine, Department of Psychology, University of New Brunswick, Fredericton, NB, Canada, eperunov@unb.ca
Heller, Daniel, Faculty of Management, Tel Aviv University, Tel Aviv, Israel
Ross, Michael, Department of Psychology, University of Waterloo, Waterloo, ON, Canada
Komar, Shawn, Department of Psychology, University of Waterloo, Waterloo, ON, Canada
Address:
Perunovic, Wei Qi Elaine, University of New Brunswick, PO Box 4400, Fredericton, NB, Canada, E3B 5A3, eperunov@unb.ca
Source:
Social Psychological and Personality Science, Vol 2(6), Nov, 2011. pp. 635-641.
Page Count:
7
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
1948-5506 (Print)
1948-5514 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
intrinsic motivation, extrinsic motivation, affective states, cultural identification
Abstract:
This study investigates the link between motivational and affective experiences in the daily life of bicultural individuals. Employing a diary design, the authors examined the role of cultural identification in the dynamic goal–affect association in East-Asian Canadian biculturals. Using multilevel modeling procedures, the authors found that momentary cultural identification systematically moderated the association between extrinsic motivation and Negative Affect (NA) over time. Similar to previous findings observed from monocultural Westerners, biculturals in this study showed a positive association between extrinsic motivation and NA when they identified with Western culture. When they identified with Asian culture, however, biculturals' extrinsic motivation was not linked to NA, suggesting that when their Asian identity is salient, they are less negatively influenced by extrinsic goal pursuit than when they identified with Western culture. Findings indicate the importance of within-individual short-term variations in cultural identification for understanding the affective implications of extrinsic motivation in the lives of bicultural individuals. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Extrinsic Motivation; *Intrinsic Motivation; *Sociocultural Factors; *Affective Valence; Cross Cultural Differences; Ethnic Identity
PsycINFO Classification:
Personality Traits & Processes (3120)
Population:

Male

Age Group:

Middle Age (40-64 yrs)

Title:
Therapeutic Considerations in Work with Biracial Girls.
Authors:
Lee, Wanda M. L., Department of Counseling, San Francisco State University, San Francisco, CA, US
Address:
Lee, Wanda M. L., Department of Counseling, San Francisco State University, BH524 CHHS, 1600 Holloway Avenue, San Francisco, CA, US, 94132
Source:
Women & Therapy, Vol 27(1-2), 2004. pp. 203-216.
Page Count:
14
Publisher:
US : Haworth Press
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
ISSN:
0270-3149 (Print)
1541-0315 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
biracial girls, developmental challenges, racial identity, monocultural existence, ethnic heritage, identity development, social relationships, sexual relationships
Abstract:
Biracial girls face all the developmental challenges of growing up female and the additional challenge of forging an identity in a society that presses them to choose a monocultural existence and disavow part of their ethnic heritage. Existing literature raises several potential issues for biracial girls in terms of identity development, social and sexual relationships, and family. Therapist ethnic awareness, client physical appearance, reasons for seeking treatment, level of identity development, and environmental considerations are discussed. Therapists are encouraged to offer a sociopolitical perspective, promote biracial/bicultural identity development, assist biracial girls in connecting with a multicultural community, and work collaboratively with parents in fostering the positive development of biracial girls. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

Biracial girls face all the developmental challenges of growing up female and the additional challenge of forging an identity in a society that presses them to choose a monocultural existence and disavow part of their ethnic heritage. Record: 162
Title:
Toward a new paradigm: A cultural systems approach.
Parent Book Series:
International and cultural psychology series
Authors:
Kagawa-Singer, Marjorie, U California, Public Health & Asian American Studies Ctr, Los Angeles, CA, US
Chung, Rita Chi-Ying, George Mason U, Graduate School of Education, Counseling & Development Program, VA, US
Source:
Asian American mental health: Assessment theories and methods. Kurasaki, Karen S. (Ed); Okazaki, Sumie (Ed); Sue, Stanley (Ed); pp. 47-66; New York, NY, US: Kluwer Academic/Plenum Publishers; 2002. xv, 344 pp.
Page Count:
20
ISBN:
0-306-47268-6 (Hardcover)
Language:
English
Keywords:
cultural influences, cultural variations, conceptualization of mental illness, theoretical perspective, mental health theory, Asian Americans
Abstract:
The purpose of this chapter is to make explicit the influence of culture on the conceptualization and construction of mental illness. The authors first examine the theoretical assumptions and methodological fallacies that underlie the assumed universal patterns of expression of mental distress rather than cultural specificity of idioms of distress. Next, they demonstrate the need for extensive rethinking and restructuring of mental health theory for Asian Americans. They offer a different theoretical perspective for assessing the mental health of Asian American clients, and broadening the monocultural, European American paradigm to promote greater sensitivity in the assessment of cultural variations in emotional distress. It is suggested that researchers and practitioners interpret behavior according to its contextual meaning and accept the equal validity of various cultural constructions of the distress. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)

*Asians; *Cross Cultural Differences; *Mental Disorders; *Sociocultural Factors; Theories

Title:
Training programs: Guidelines for multicultural transformation.
Authors:
Green, Robert-Jay, California School of Professional Psychology-Berkeley/Alameda, Family/Child Psychology Training, Alameda, CA, US
Source:
Re-visioning family therapy: Race, culture, and gender in clinical practice. McGoldrick, Monica (Ed); pp. 111-117; New York, NY, US: Guilford Press; 1998. xx, 444 pp.
Page Count:
7
ISBN:
1-57230-027-2 (Hardcover)
Language:
English
Keywords:
guidelines for multicultural transformation of predominantly White family therapy training programs
Abstract:
Multicultural transformation of predominantly White training programs (which includes almost all programs in the field of family therapy) is difficult and typically is characterized by a series of wrenching crises and ultimate resolutions. The process requires a long-term commitment to organizational self-examination. This chapter describes 11 guidelines for multicultural transformation of predominantly White, monocultural family therapy training programs. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)

Transforming counseling courses: From monocultural to multicultural.

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 165
Title:
Transitions in professional training.
Parent Book Series:
International and cultural psychology; ISSN: 1574-0455 (Print)
Authors:
Dana, Richard H., Portland State University, Regional Research Institute for Human Services, Portland, OR, US
Address:
Dana, Richard H., Portland State University, Regional Research Institute for Human Services, Portland, OR, US, 97201
Source:
Cultural competency training in a global society. Dana, Richard H. (Ed); Allen, James (Ed); pp. 95-112; New York, NY, US: Springer Science + Business Media; 2008. xxx, 252 pp.
Page Count:
18
ISSN:
1574-0455 (Print)
ISBN:
978-0-387-79821-9 (Hardcover)
978-0-387-79822-6 (PDF)
Language:
English
Keywords:
transitions, monocultural perspective, professional psychology, training, education, multicultural competency, Cube Model, sociocultural diversities, practice
Abstract:
This chapter examines transitions from a monocultural perspective toward a multicultural perspective embodied in a model for education, training, and professional practice in psychology. A rich history of Child and Adolescent Service System Program advocacy, followed by exemplars, demonstrations, practice models and guidelines, chronicled the development and implementation of a multicultural perspective. The development of a multicultural perspective was accompanied by an increasing diversity of students, faculty, and professional service providers. At present, however, multicultural education is imperfectly represented in professional psychology training programs and by services in the public and private sectors. The recent Cube Model is a contemporary stimulus toward more coherent, comprehensive, and competency-oriented education in training programs incorporating a multicultural perspective. The Cube Model foundational domain of individual and cultural diversity was fleshed out by an expansion of the counseling psychology triadic training model to include California Brief Multicultural Competence Scale (CBMCS) measurement of a fourth factor, Sociocultural Diversities. This new factor extends the conceptualization of multicultural competency to include multiple identities and contexts represented by the poor, aged, disabled, gender, and gay/lesbian populations. The CBMCS is one component of the Multicultural Assessment-Intervention Process (MAIP) practice model for systematically including multicultural issues in services and service delivery. A multicultural competency training model complements the Cube Model by articulating components germane to multicultural education. These components address implementation within training programs by selection of students, more comprehensive competency-oriented training employing diverse modalities, and routine evaluation of educational-training outcomes. Two illustrative programs suggest how these components can be incorporated into graduate training. These programs articulate both the difficulties and the promise of training agendas that incorporate both Cube Model components and CBMCS/MAIP procedures into multicultural education. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)
Subjects:
*Cultural Sensitivity; *Graduate Psychology Education; *Models; *Training; *Multiculturalism; Clinical Practice; Competence; Diversity; Ethnocentrism; Sociocultural Factors

Abstract:
This chapter examines psychological science in the United States characterized historically as ethnocentric and monocultural. PsycINFO
Record: 167
Title:
Treatment of multicultural counseling in correctional psychology textbooks.
Authors:
Young, Thomas J., Washburn U, Topeka, KS, US
Source:
Psychological Reports, Vol 65(2), Oct, 1989. pp. 521-522.
Page Count:
2
Publisher:
US : Psychological Reports
ISSN:
0033-2941 (Print)
1558-691X (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
coverage of multicultural counseling in correctional psychology textbooks, 1977–88
Abstract:
Acontent analysis of 12 correctional psychology textbooks (published 1977–1988) examined the extent to which the texts incorporate topics related to multicultural counseling (MCC). Only 2 books briefly mentioned the topic of MCC, and neither provided a systematic discussion of MCC. Five books included the subject of "special clients" but did not include racial/ethnic minorities. In 5 other books, treatment issues and modalities were given a monocultural presentation. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Counseling; *Cross Cultural Differences; *Forensic Psychology; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Textbooks; Psychology Education; Multicultural Counseling

Curriculum & Programs & Teaching Methods (3530)

Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=1990-13339-001&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Treatment of multicultural counseling in correctional psychology textbooks.</A>
Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 168
Title:
Trust, discrimination and acculturation: Experimental evidence on Asian international and Australian domestic university students.
Authors:
Guillen, Pablo, Discipline of Economics, University of Sydney, Sydney, NSW, Australia, pablo.guillenalvarez@sydney.edu.au
Ji, Daniel, Reserve Bank of Australia, Sydney, NSW, Australia
Address:
Guillen, Pablo, Discipline of Economics, University of Sydney, Room 340, Merewether Building, Sydney, NSW, Australia, 2006, pablo.guillenalvarez@sydney.edu.au
Source:
The Journal of Socio-Economics, Vol 40(5), Oct, 2011. pp. 594-608.
Page Count:
15
Publisher:
Netherlands : Elsevier Science
Other Journal Titles:
Journal of Behavioral Economics; Journal of Behavioral and Experimental Economics
ISSN:
1053-5357 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
Asian international university students, Australian domestic university students, trust, student discrimination
Abstract:
Migrations have intensified with the advent of globalisation. Societies once solidly monocultural are becoming increasingly multicultural. It is, however, not clear how social capital would travel across cultural boundaries. A multicultural environment might result on agents preferring to interact with those of their own culture, discriminating against others. We study trust, an aspect of social capital, between domestic Australian students of non-Asian origin and international students of Asian origin. To measure the degree of trust and patterns of discrimination between these groups, the Berg et al. (1995) trust game and a series of control games were used in framework where each participant played each game against several partners knowing their domestic or international status. Controlling for individual heterogeneity, domestic students significantly discriminated against international students in the trust game, and individual discrimination was taste-based rather than based on beliefs towards international students’ trustworthiness. Moreover, the average amount that international students sent in the trust game was negatively related with the number of semesters studied at university in Australia, which may partly reflect cultural adjustment but also institutional disadvantages faced specifically by international students. The study furthers understanding of the patterns of discrimination between domestic and international university students and the nature of this discrimination. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*College Students; *Cross Cultural Differences; *International Students; *Race and Ethnic Discrimination; *Trust (Social Behavior)
PsycINFO Classification:
Classroom Dynamics & Student Adjustment & Attitudes (3560)
Culture & Ethnology (2930)
Population:
Human
Male
Female
Location:
Australia
Age Group:
Adulthood (18 yrs & older)
Methodology:

PsycINFO
Record: 169
Title:
Uncovering preservice teachers' beliefs about diversity through reflective writing.
Authors:
Kyles, Carli R., Urban Education Department, University of Houston Downtown, Houston, TX, US, kylesc@uhd.edu
Olafson, Lori, University of Nevada Las Vegas, Las Vegas, NV, US
Address:
Kyles, Carli R., Urban Education Department, University of Houston Downtown, One Main St., Commerce Building-430S, Houston, TX, US, 77007, kylesc@uhd.edu
Source:
Urban Education, Vol 43(5), Sep, 2008. pp. 500-518.
Page Count:
19
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
0042-0859 (Print)
1552-8340 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
preservice teachers beliefs, diversity, reflective writing, multicultural education
Abstract:
This article reports findings from a mixed-method investigation of a cohort of teacher candidates who were placed in an urban and culturally diverse practicum site at an elementary school. Fifteen preservice teachers completed pre- and posttest measures related to hope, motivation for teaching, and efficacy for teaching. Throughout the semester, they were required to investigate personal beliefs and past experiences with cultural diversity in the form of writing reflective response letters and cultural autobiographies. Providing the students with these opportunities was beneficial; however, findings are consistent with previous studies that suggest that (a) multiple opportunities across time are needed to uncover and dialogue about beliefs to present significant change rather than single, isolated opportunities and (b) teacher candidates with multicultural schooling and life experiences are more likely to have favorable beliefs and attitudes regarding cultural diversity than are candidates with monocultural schooling and life experiences. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Creative Writing; *Diversity; *Preservice Teachers; *Reflectiveness; *Teacher Attitudes; Multicultural Education
PsycINFO Classification:

Record: 170
Title:
Use of evaluative devices by youth for sense-making of culturally diverse interpersonal interactions.
Authors:
Lucić, Luka, Department of Social Sciences and Cultural Studies, Pratt Institute, Brooklyn, NY, US, llucic@pratt.edu
Address:
Lucić, Luka, llucic@pratt.edu
Source:
International Journal of Intercultural Relations, Vol 37(4), Jul, 2013. pp. 434-449.
Page Count:
16
Publisher:
Netherlands : Elsevier Science
ISSN:
0147-1767 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
cultural diversity, interpersonal interactions, language evaluation, sense making, psychological development
Abstract:
Building upon recent research that defines psychological development as a continuous process of sense-making situated within a cultural and historical context, this paper explores how culturally diverse youth growing up in New York City use evaluative language to enact relational complexity as they make sense of technologically mediated interpersonal interactions with their peers. Forty-four individuals (ages 15–20) participated in a quasi-experimental research workshop that engaged them in the process of sense-making by asking them to write projective narratives toward a vignette depicting text-massage mediated interpersonal interaction embedded among monocultural and bicultural group of peers. Data analyses focus on evaluative devices used by youth and manifest the relational flexibility of sense-making by immigrant youth and their U.S. born peers across diverse relational dimensions. Results suggest that immigrant youth are able to coordinate diverse ways of interpreting interpersonal interactions across relational dimensions, manifest by varied use of logical/hypothetical, causal and affective evaluative devices. In contrast U.S. born youth largely use same frequency of evaluative devices across two relational dimensions. Statistical analysis highlights the use of affect in projective narratives by exploring a discursive learning hypothesis: that higher use of emotions in the process of sense-making by U.S. born youth gradually scaffolds the use of emotions in narrative by immigrant youth. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Cross Cultural Differences; *Interpersonal Interaction; *Psychological Development; *Sense of Coherence; Language; Urban Environments
PsycINFO Classification:
Psychosocial & Personality Development (2840)
Population:

Male

US

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 171
Title:
When Diversity Becomes the Norm.
Parent Book Series:
Race and ethnicity in psychology
Authors:
Daughtry, Donald, Department of Counseling, University of North Dakota, Grand Forks, ND, US
Twohey, Denise, University of North Dakota, Grand Forks, ND, US
Whitcomb, David H., University of North Dakota, Grand Forks, ND, US
Juntunen, Cindy, Department of Counseling, University of North Dakota, Grand Forks, ND, US
Loewy, Michael, University of North Dakota, Grand Forks, ND, US
Source:
The psychology of prejudice and discrimination: Disability, religion, physique, and other traits, Vol. 4. Chin, Jean Lau (Ed); pp. 253-281; Westport, CT, US: Praeger Publishers/Greenwood Publishing Group; 2005. xv, 304 pp.
Page Count:
29
ISBN:
0-275-98238-6 (Hardcover)
Language:
English
Keywords:
multicultural competency, ethnocentric, diversity, faculty, organizational diversity, organizational multicultural development
Abstract:
The goal of this chapter is to illustrate the efforts of one academic department to change from an ethnocentric to a multicultural organization. The authors describe an evolution of organizational diversity and individual experiences in a department of counseling, which is home to a master of arts in counseling and a PhD in counseling psychology, and is staffed by six full-time faculty and two part-time faculty. In the author's department's effort to evolve to an environment where diversity is the norm, they have chosen to explore how multicultural competency impacts their work as a group, as well as their work as individuals. The changes they have made over the last decade reflect the developmental stages of organizational multicultural development described by D. W. Sue (1995): monocultural, nondiscriminatory, and multicultural. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)
Subjects:
*College Teachers; *Competence; *Ethnocentrism; *Organizational Behavior; *Multiculturalism; Diversity in the Workplace

Database:

Record: 172
Title:
White children in a multi-cultural school setting: A valid cause for concern?
Authors:
Faulkner, Joy, Birmingham Psychological Service, Central Team, England
Source:
Educational Studies, Vol 16(2), 1990. pp. 109-116.
Page Count:
8
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
ISSN:
0305-5698 (Print)
1465-3400 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
social & emotional & scholastic adjustment & ethnic differences, White students in multicultural vs monocultural elementary schools, England
Abstract:
Compared the social, emotional, and scholastic adjustment of a group of indigenous White children attending a multicultural school with that of a similar group being educated in a monocultural, predominantly White setting. A secondary aim was to investigate interethnic differences between the cultural groups represented: 94 indigenous White, 19 Afro-Caribbean, and 70 Asian 9–21 yr olds. The null hypothesis that no significant differences would appear between the responses of White pupils attending the multicultural school and those of controls attending the monocultural school was sustained. Some interethnic differences emerged, but gender rather than cultural background or type of school attended was the major source of difference in response. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Adjustment; *Multicultural Education; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Whites; Elementary School Students; Emotional Adjustment; School Adjustment; Social Adjustment

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 173
Title:
Why is multiculturalism good?
Authors:
Fowers, Blaine J., U Miami, Dept of Educational & Psychological Studies, Coral Gables, FL, US
Richardson, Frank C.
Source:
American Psychologist, Vol 51(6), Jun, 1996. pp. 609-621.
Page Count:
13
Publisher:
US : American Psychological Association
ISSN:
0003-066X (Print)
1935-990X (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
moral perspectives on & paradox in multicultural reassessment of psychology
Abstract:
This article explores the moral sources that give multiculturalism the potency to move psychology to reassess itself. The power of the multicultural perspective appears to derive from its ability to show how psychology's tendency toward monocultural universalism has undermined its aims as a science of human behavior and promoter of human welfare. The multicultural critique also draws on Euro-American moral traditions and ideals, such as individual rights, authenticity, respect, and tolerance. In spite of the importance of these ideals, multiculturalists often criticize Euro-American culture without acknowledging their debt to it. Moreover, these particularist moral sources undercut multiculturalism's universalist appeal. There is a paradoxical tendency among some advocates of multiculturalism to encourage cultural separatism and an inarticulateness in dealing with intercultural value conflict. We present some recommendations for dealing with these dilemmas from philosophical hermeneutics, including the contextualization of multiculturalism, an approach to sifting and evaluating cultural values, and an ontological account of the dialogical nature of humans. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Cross Cultural Differences; *Cultural Sensitivity; *Morality; *Psychology
PsycINFO Classification:
Culture & Ethnology (2930)
Population:
Human
Format Covered:
Print
Publication Type:
Journal; Peer Reviewed Journal
Document Type:
Journal Article
Release Date:
19960101

20140421

American Psychological Association. 1996

http://dx.doi.org.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/10.1037/0003-066X.51.6.609

1996-04950-003
